##Ellison and Glaeser Summary
Research Question:
\begin{enumerate}
  \item{Is it possible to create indices of geographic concentration and coagglomeration that control for industry differences?}
  \item{Are observed levels of concentration greater than would be expected to arise randomly?}
\end{enumerate}

Results: \newline
--Slight concentration is highly prevalent.\newline
--Gamma values between 0 and .6\newline
--Wide variation in coagglomeration across industries.\newline

Method:\newline
--Create indices of agglomeration "$\gamma$" and coagglomeration "$\gamma^c$" \newline
--Compare manufacturing industries in the US

##Ellison and Glaeser Agglomeration Metric

$$\gamma = \frac{G-(1-X)H}{(1-X)(1-H)}$$

where $G=\sum(s_i-x_i)^2$, $H=\sum{z_k^2}$, and $X=\sum{x_i^2}$
\begin{itemize} \itemsep1em
  \item{$z_k$ is a measure of each plant's size}
    \begin{itemize}
    \item{given by each plant's share of industry employment}
  \end{itemize}
  \item{$s_i$ is each area's share of the industry employment}
  \begin{itemize}
    \item{the sum of all $z_k$ in each area}
  \end{itemize}
  \item{$x_i$ is each area's share of overall manufacturing employment}
\end{itemize}


##Ellison and Glaeser Coagglomeration Metric

$$\gamma^c=\frac{[\frac{G}{(1-X)}]-H-\sum_{j=1}^r{\hat\gamma_jw_j^2(1-H_j)}}{1-\sum_{j=1}^rw^2_j}$$


The variables I need to replicate $\gamma^c$ are:
\begin{enumerate}
  \item{G, the raw concentration of employment in the group as a whole}
  \item{H, the plant size Herfindahl of the group as a whole}
  \item{$X$, the Herfindahl of $x_i$, each area's share of overall manufacturing employment}
  \item{$\hat\gamma_j$, the gamma of the jth industry in the group}
  \item{$w_j$, the jth industry's employment share of the group}
  \item{$H_j$, the plant size Herfindahl of the jth industry}
\end{enumerate}

##Simulation Conclusions
\begin{itemize}
  \item Size of geographic units doesn't matter
  \item Bigger total area -- higher gamma
  \item Larger organizations means gamma closer to 0
  \item More organizations for a given core code means gamma closer to 0
\end{itemize}
